titleStmt.title: APology To Lady Carteret in Ireland

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: on her inviting Dr Swift to Dinner, when he came my Lady not being at home the Dr went away; at her Ladyships return she enquird for him and hearing what had passd sent the nex Day again to invite him, when he came the Day after he began to make an Apology for his going away, but her Ladyship told him she woud have none but in Verse which occasiond the following my Lady,
A Lady wise as well as fair,
Whose conscience always was her care,
Thoughtful upon a point of moment,
Wou'd know the Text as well as comment;
Hearing of a grave Divine
She sent to bid him come and dine:
But you must know he was not quite
So grave as to be unpolite,
Thought human Learning wou'd not lessen
The Dignity of his profession
And if you heard the man discourse
Or preach, you'd like him ne'er the worse
He long had bid the Court farewell,
Retreating to his private Cell,
Suspected for the Love he bore
To one who sway'd some time before;
Which made it more surprizing how
He shoud be sent for thither now.
The message told he gapes and stares,
And scarce believes his Eyes or Ears.
Could not conceive what it shoud mean,
And fain would have it told again:
But then the Squire so trim and nice,
'Twas rude to make him tell it twice;
So bow'd was thankful for the Honour
And wou'd not fail to wait upon her.
His Beaver brush'd, his shoes and gown,
Away he trudges into town;
Passes the Castle Tower yard,
And now advancing thro' the guard,
He trembles at the thought of state,
For conscious of his sheepish gait,
His spirits of a sudden faild him
He stoop'd and cou'd not tell what ail'd him
“What was the message I receiv'd?
“Why certainly the Captain rav'd.
“To dine with her and come at three!
“Impossible it cou'd be me:
“It may be I mistook the word,
“My Lady,──── It must be my Lord;
“My Lord's abroad my Lady too,
“What must th'unhappy Doctor do?
“Is Captain Cratcherode here pray?──── no;
“Nay──── then tis time for me to go;
“Am I awake or do I dream?
“I'm sure he call'd me by my name
“Nam'd me as plain as he coud speak
“And yet there must be some mistake;
“Why what shou'd I, I pray, have been,
“Now had my Lady been within?
“What cou'd I've said? I'm mighty glad
“She went abroad──── she'd thought me mad
“The hour of dining now is pass'd
“Well then──── I'll e'en go home and fast
“And since I've scap'd being made \add a\ scoff
“I think I'm very fairly off.”
My Lady now returning home,
Calld── Cratchrode,──── is the Doctor come?
He had not heard of him──── pray see,
'Tis now a Quarter after three.
The Captain walks about and searches
Thro all the Rooms and Courts and Arches,
Examining all the Servants round
In vain, no Doctor's to be found.
My Lady coud not chuse but wonder,
`Captain, I fear you've made some blunder:
`But pray to morrow go at ten,
`I'll try his manners once again,
`If rudeness is th' effect of knowledge
`My son shall never see a College.'
The Captain was a man of reading,
And mirth, good sense as well as breeding.
Who loth to blame as to incense,
Said little in his own defence.
Next day another message brought
The Doctor frighted at his fault,
Is drest and stealing thro' the Croud
Now pale as Death, now blush'd and bow'd,
Panting & fault'ring hum'd & haw'd,
`Her Ladyship was gone abroad;
`The Captain too──── he did not know,
`Whether he ought to stay or go;
`Begg'd she'd forgive him,──── In conclusion
My Lady pity'd his confusion,
Call'd her good nature to relieve him
Told him she thought she might believe him.
And woud not only grant his suit,
But visit him and eat some fruit,
Provided at a proper time,
He told the real truth in rhyme.
'Twas to no purpose to oppose
She'd hear of no excuse in prose.
The Doctor stood not to debate
Glad to compound at any rate:
So bowing, seemingly comply'd,
Tho if he durst he had deny'd,
But first resolv'd to show his taste
Was too refind to make a feast
He'd treat with nothing that was rare,
But winding walks and purer air;
He'd entertain without expence
Or pride or vain magnificence,
For well he knew for such a guest
The plainest meat must be the best.
To stomachs clog'd with costly fare,
Simplicity alone is rare:
Whilst high, and nice, and curious meats,
Are really but vulgar treats.
Instead of spoils of persian looms
The costly boasts of regal rooms,
Thought it more courtly and discreet
To scatter roses at her feet:
Roses of richest dye that shone
With native lustre like her own;
Beauty that needs no aid of art,
Thro' ev'ry sense to reach the heart.
The gracious dame altho' she knew
All this was much beneath her due,
Like'd ev'ry thing, at least thought fit
To praise it par maniere d'acquit.
But yet tho seeming pleasd can't bear
The scorching Sun or chilling air
Frighted alike at both extremes,
If he displays or hides his beams:
Tho seeming pleasd at all she sees,
Starts at the rustling of the Trees;
Can scarcly speak for want of breath,
In half a walk fatigu'd to Death.
The Doctor takes his hints from hence
To vindicate his late offence:
Madam the mighty power of use
Now strongly pleads in my excuse,
If you unus'd have scarcely strength
To move this walk's untoward length;
If started at a scene so rude,
Thro long disuse of solitude;
If long confind to fires and screens,
You dread the waving of these greens;
If trees that neither see nor hear,
Nor speak nor walk can give you fear
If you who long have breath'd the fumes
Of city fogs and crowded rooms.
Do now sollicitously shun
The cooling air and daz'ling Sun;
If Sol's majestick eye you flee,
Learn hence t'excuse and pity me
Consider what it is to bear
The powder'd Courties witty sneer;
To see th'important man of dress
Joking my college aukwardness:
To be the strutting Cornet's sport
To run the Gantlet of the Court,
Winding my way by slow approaches
Tho' crowd of Coxcombs and of Coaches.
From the first fierce cockaded Centry,
Quite thro' the tribe of waiting Gentry;
To pass so many crouded stages,
And stand the staring of your pages;
And after all to crown my spleen,
Be told you are not to be seen,
── Or if you are── be forc'd to bear
The awe of your majestick air.
And can I then be faulty found,
In dreading this vexatious round?
Can it be strange, if I eschew
A Scene so glorious and so new?
Or is he criminal who flies
The living lustre of your Eyes?
